title: Misappropriation and Corruption involving Pashupati Area Development Trust Land in Gothatar
description:
This case concerns two major issues involving 534 ropani of land owned by the Pashupati Area Development Trust (PADT) in Gothatar, Kageshwari Manohara Municipality, Kathmandu. The land has been subject to a long-standing illegal encroachment by squatters and was also the site of a significant corruption scandal related to illegal sand quarrying, which resulted in the conviction of high-level officials and contractors by the Supreme Court.

1. Sand Quarrying Corruption Case:

On January 23, 2015, the Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA) filed a corruption case against nine individuals, including former PADT Member-Secretaries and Local Development Officers. They were accused of illegally awarding a contract for sand and soil excavation to CN Construction, causing a loss of approximately NPR 46 crore (460 million) to the state. The allegations included collusion, awarding the contract without due process, and allowing excavation beyond the permitted scope and without a proper Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA).

While the Special Court acquitted seven officials in 2016, the CIAA appealed the decision. On January 23, 2024, the Supreme Court overturned the acquittal and convicted all nine defendants, imposing prison sentences and substantial fines. The convicted individuals include former PADT Member-Secretaries Nirmal Kuinkel and Sushil Nahata, who were each sentenced to six years in prison.

2. Illegal Land Encroachment:

The same 534-ropani plot has been continuously encroached upon for years by individuals claiming to be landless squatters (sukumbasi). The history of this dispute is contentious, marked by events such as a reported arson attack in 1998 on an official who opposed the settlement. The PADT has made numerous unsuccessful attempts to reclaim the land, including issuing public notices and attempting to clear illegal structures.

In early 2024, a renewed effort was launched under the direction of the Minister for Culture, Tourism, and Civil Aviation, Sudan Kirati. The PADT began collaborating with the Kathmandu Metropolitan City (KMC), led by Mayor Balen Shah, to demarcate and remove all illegal structures. The PADT has designated this land for major development projects under its master plan, including a Pashupati Hindu University, a large cowshed (Gaushala), an Ayurveda dispensary, and a public park.
unverified_info:
The raw research material contained several future dates for the Supreme Court verdict and the release of its full text, citing them as occurring in 2025 (2081/2082 BS). These have been corrected to the verified dates in 2024 (2080/2081 BS) based on credible news reports. The original source URLs containing these incorrect future dates have been omitted in favor of verified sources.

  • While the total land area is 534 ropani, the exact monetary value of the loss due to encroachment is not quantified, though land prices in the area are known to be extremely high.
  • The precise number of illegal structures or encroaching families is not consistently reported.
  • Details of the 1998 arson attack on the home of local official Sanobabu Chaapain are based on news reports recalling the history of the dispute and may require further primary verification.
key_allegations: Corruption in awarding a sand quarrying contract without due process
Embezzlement of funds and causing financial loss of approximately NPR 46 crore to the Pashupati Area Development Trust
Collusion between PADT officials, District Development Committee officials, and private contractors
Illegal excavation and sale of sand and soil from PADT land
Illegal encroachment and occupation of 534 ropani of PADT land by squatters
related_entities: Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA)
Ministry of Culture, Tourism, and Civil Aviation

timeline.title: Arson Attack on Local Official
timeline.description: The house of a newly elected local official, Sanobabu Chaapain, who opposed the encroachment on PADT land, was reportedly set on fire. The exact date in 1998 (2054 BS) is not specified.

timeline.title: CIAA Files Corruption Case
timeline.description: The CIAA filed a corruption case at the Special Court against nine individuals, alleging embezzlement of NPR 465.4 million in a sand quarrying contract on PADT land.

timeline.title: Special Court Acquits Seven Officials
timeline.description: The Special Court acquitted seven accused officials, including former PADT Member-Secretaries Nirmal Kuinkel and Sushil Nahata, while convicting two contractors.

timeline.title: PADT Publishes Notice to Vacate
timeline.description: The PADT published a public notice on Chaitra 11, 2076 BS, ordering the removal of illegal structures from its encroached land. Action was reportedly stalled by the COVID-19 pandemic.

timeline.title: Reports Highlight Intensified Encroachment
timeline.description: News reports indicated that encroachment was increasing, with new huts being built, particularly during the COVID-19 lockdown period.

timeline.title: PADT Issues 15-Day Ultimatum
timeline.description: PADT issued another public notice, giving a 15-day deadline for the removal of all illegally built huts and structures from its Gothatar land.

timeline.title: Supreme Court Convicts All Nine Accused
timeline.description: A Supreme Court bench overturned the Special Court's 2016 acquittal, finding all nine individuals, including officials and contractors, guilty in the sand quarrying corruption case.

timeline.title: Minister Directs Removal of Illegal Structures
timeline.description: Minister for Culture, Tourism, and Civil Aviation Sudan Kirati instructed PADT officials to promptly coordinate and clear all illegal structures from the Trust's land.

timeline.title: PADT and KMC Begin Land Demarcation
timeline.description: In collaboration with a technical team from Kathmandu Metropolitan City, PADT began the process of identifying and demarcating encroached structures for removal.

timeline.title: Supreme Court Releases Full Verdict Text
timeline.description: The full text of the Supreme Court's judgment, detailing the sentences and fines for the nine convicted individuals in the sand quarrying case, was made public.
